results.title: Our native shore
results.creator_credit: Esso Film Unit, British Information Services, Andrew Rice and Ronald Stark
results.brief_description: Shows the people whose lives and work are centred directly on the coastal areas of the British Isles and to whom the sea and ships are a part of their lives. Fisherman, coast guard, merchant seaman, life boat man, harbourmaster, shipwright, yachtsman, lighthouse keeper and a score of others move against a background rich in natural beauty and historical associations.

results.title: Our national heritage: the living pattern
results.creator_credit: Pilot Films, National Benzole, Ralph Keene and John Taylor
results.brief_description: Britain’s wildlife is the theme of this film. It shows most of the principal surviving wild animals in Britain, then the work of the Nature Conservancy in preserving them in nature reserves and elsewhere, and in carrying out ecological research.

results.title: Our Mutual friend
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Catherine Wearing and Julian Farino
results.brief_description: Based on Charles Dickens last completed novel, this production paints a sweeping picture of London in the 19th century. With its themes of class war, sexual jealousy and overwhelming passion, it is a tale that is as relevant today as when Dickens first penned it.

results.title: Our melancholy duty
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Bee Reynolds, Will Davies and Look Television Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “When the war came to Australia”.
Although Australians rushed to support Britain in her war with Germany, it was not until Tobruk that Australians at home really cared about the war, and not until Dunkirk that they took Hitler seriously. Mothers and wives left at home take up the traditional supporting roles and the Women’s Services are formed, but soon the daily casualty lists begin to appear and the heartbreak and dread begin. Personal recollections, rare archival footage and the music of the time combine to create an evocative and haunting picture of this unique period in Australia’s history.

results.title: Our Matt
results.creator_credit: Noel Withers, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Noel Withers is very proud of his son Matt. Born with Crouzon Syndrome, Matt suffered hearing loss, facial abnomalities and had to undergo numerous procedures to accommodate brain growth. Some operations were more successful than others, but Matt faced them all with a determination that inspired admiration in those around him.

results.title: Our living past
results.creator_credit: Austral Pacific Productions, Andrew J. Helgeson and Peter Thompson
results.brief_description: Deals with Australia’s heritage of historic places and buildings existing today, to be used and enjoyed by all. Describes Macquarie’s Old Government House, Sydney, The Rocks, Sydney; Royal Theatre, Hobart; Port Arthur, Tasmania; Windsor Hotel, Melbourne; the Lunatic Asylum, Perth; and many other places throughout Australia Photographed by Peter Leyden and Hans Heidrich. Sound by Kevin McLellan. Commentator, Tim Elliot.

results.title: Our lighthouse adventure
results.creator_credit: Queenscliff Primary School and Lisa Kebbell
results.brief_description:
Created as part of an investigation into the lighthouses of Queenscliff. The Queenscliff Primary School students wanted to write an adventure story in which they were the stars. It was also a way in which they could convey some of the information they had learnt about lighthouses to an audience in an entertaining way.
A photomontage accompanied by commentary from the students on CD ROM.

results.title: Our land, our water
results.creator_credit: New Zealand National Film Unit, Tom Williamson and John King
results.brief_description: A satirical presentation of the exploitation of resources of land, water and people, with the difficulties of satisfying conflicting needs. The responsibility to all users is raised, with the needs of the future in mind. Cast includes Stephen Tozer, Marjorie Brooke-White, Bob Walker, Allan Richards, Kenneth R. Hobman.

results.title: Our land, our truth = Debout sur leur terre
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Jean Dansereau and Maurice Bulbulian
results.brief_description: Made in collaboration with the Inuit Tungavingat Nunamini, this film focuses on those dissident members of the Inuit community who rejected the agreement signed on November 11, l975, between the Northern Quebec Inuit Association, the Quebec and federal governments, the James Bay Energy Corporation, the James Bay Development Corporation, Hydro-Quebec and the Grand Council of the Crees, which took away Native rights to a territory of almost one million square kilometres. By their words and actions, the dissident Inuit of Povungnituk, Ivujivik and Sugluk express their strong desire to retain their land and their traditions. The filmmakers go into their homes, on the ice and the sea to record first-hand the lives of these northern people. In French and Inuit with no subtitles.
